speaker: NURSE
text: Hello, I’m your nurse here in the Emergency Department. I see you just came from dialysis because they were worried about your blood pressure and a positive blood culture. How are you feeling right now—any dizziness, shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, or chills?

speaker: PATIENT
text: I feel a little tired, but that’s how I usually feel after dialysis. No chest pain or trouble breathing. I don’t feel feverish. I did have chills at dialysis the other day, but not right now. My blood pressure is always kind of low, they tell me.

speaker: NURSE
text: Thanks for telling me. The triage vitals show your blood pressure is on the low side, but that may be your baseline. The doctors are also concerned about that positive blood culture from dialysis, so they’ve started IV antibiotics here. I’m going to put you on the monitor and get some blood work while we wait for the ICU team to see you.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Hi, I’m one of the medicine residents. I’ve reviewed your chart: you have HIV, end-stage kidney disease on hemodialysis through a left subclavian catheter, atrial fibrillation, and trigeminal neuralgia. You were sent in because your blood cultures from dialysis grew bacteria and your blood pressure has been low. Can you walk me through what happened at dialysis over the last few days?

speaker: PATIENT
text: A couple of days ago during dialysis I got really cold and sweaty. They took some blood cultures and gave me an antibiotic through the machine. Then they called me back because the culture was positive, and today during dialysis my pressure dropped again, but they finished the treatment. They told me to come here.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: That matches what we have. The culture from dialysis showed gram-positive cocci in clusters, which is often a staph-type bacteria, and you received cefazolin and vancomycin there. Here in the ED you’ve gotten another broad-spectrum antibiotic. Your blood pressure is in the 80s to 90s systolic, which may be your baseline, but we’re being cautious because of the positive culture and your HIV. We’re going to admit you to the ICU for close monitoring and IV antibiotics.

speaker: PATIENT
text: ICU? Am I that sick? I don’t feel that bad, just tired and a little lightheaded like after dialysis.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’re not seeing signs of severe infection right now—no fever, your exam is reassuring, and your chest X-ray doesn’t show pneumonia. But with your low blood pressure, positive blood culture, and HIV, we want to watch you closely. In the ICU we can monitor your blood pressure continuously, give fluids carefully since you’re on dialysis, and adjust your antibiotics. If everything stays stable, we can move you out quickly.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay, as long as someone explains what’s going on. My pressure is always low, they tell me at dialysis it’s in the 70s or 80s sometimes.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your nephrologist confirmed that your usual systolic blood pressure is in the 80s to 90s, especially around dialysis, so that helps us interpret today’s numbers. We’ll still give you a small amount of IV fluid to see if that helps and keep an eye on your labs and lactate. If your blood pressure and symptoms stay at your baseline, that’s reassuring.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: I’m the ICU attending. I’ve reviewed your ED course and your history of HIV, ESRD on hemodialysis, atrial fibrillation, and trigeminal neuralgia. Your blood pressure is low but consistent with your reported baseline, and your lactate has improved after fluids. We’re going to continue IV vancomycin to treat the staph from your line and repeat blood cultures to make sure the infection is clearing.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Will you have to take out my dialysis catheter because of the infection?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Right now, the plan from the nephrology team is to treat through the infection with IV vancomycin given with dialysis for about two weeks, rather than removing the catheter immediately. We’ll watch your repeat blood cultures; if they stay negative and you remain stable, we can keep the line. If cultures stayed positive or you got sicker, we’d reconsider removing it.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I also get this sharp pain on the right side of my face and over my eye sometimes. It’s been there before from shingles, they said. It’s not too bad right now.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: That sounds like your trigeminal neuralgia from prior shingles. We’ll continue your pain medicines like oxycodone as needed and gabapentin, and we’ll keep you on valacyclovir as you were taking at home.

speaker: NURSE
text: We’re getting you settled in the ICU now. You’re on the heart monitor and blood pressure cuff. If you feel more lightheaded, short of breath, or have chest pain, please call right away. I’ll also be giving your regular HIV and dialysis-related medications as ordered.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Thank you. I usually feel dizzy and short of breath after dialysis until the next day, so I’ll let you know if it’s worse than usual.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’ve reviewed your morning labs. Your white blood cell count is low at 2.9, and your platelets are around 98, which is similar to your prior labs and likely related to your HIV. Your kidney numbers are high as expected with ESRD, and your potassium is mildly elevated at 5.4. Your lactate is normal at 1.7, which is reassuring against severe sepsis.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So the infection isn’t making my blood bad right now?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your blood counts haven’t dropped suddenly, and you don’t have a high white count or fever. That, plus the normal lactate and clear chest X-ray, makes a severe bloodstream infection less likely at this moment. We still think the positive culture from your line is real, so we’re treating it with vancomycin and repeating blood cultures to be safe.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Alright. I just don’t want to end up on a breathing machine or something.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Right now your oxygen level is good on room air, your lungs sound clear, and your chest X-ray doesn’t show any pneumonia. We have no indication that you’ll need a breathing machine, and we’ll keep monitoring you closely.

speaker: NURSE
text: I’m here to draw some more blood for your morning labs—checking your blood counts, kidney function, and electrolytes again. This helps the team see how you’re doing overnight.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I feel about the same, maybe a little tired. No new pain.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your new labs are back. Your potassium is 5.4, which is a bit high, and your kidney numbers are up, which we expect between dialysis sessions. We’re going to give you a medication by mouth called Kayexalate to help bring the potassium down while we coordinate your next dialysis.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Is that why I feel a little funny in my chest sometimes?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: High potassium can affect the heart, but your current level is only mildly elevated. We’re treating it early to prevent problems. We’re also watching your heart rhythm on the monitor because you have a history of atrial fibrillation.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: This morning your potassium spiked higher on a repeat lab—up to 7.9—so we treated that urgently and rechecked it. The follow-up labs show it has come back down to around 5.1 and then 4.1 later in the evening, which is much safer.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Wow, that sounds scary. I did feel my heart racing earlier.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: You did go into a fast heart rhythm—atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. We gave you IV diltiazem to slow your heart rate and then started you on diltiazem pills four times a day. Your heart rate has come down nicely.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Is that a new medicine I’ll have to keep taking at home?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Yes. The diltiazem tablets are new for you, and you’ll continue them after discharge to help keep your heart rate controlled. We’ll include it in your discharge prescriptions and instructions.

speaker: CONSULT
text: I’m from the nephrology team. We’re following you for your end-stage renal disease and the line infection. You’ll continue your usual Monday-Wednesday-Friday dialysis schedule, and we’ll give vancomycin with dialysis for about 11 more days to complete a two-week course. We’ll also be careful not to remove too much fluid during dialysis, since aggressive fluid removal seems to drop your blood pressure and make you feel dizzy and short of breath.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yes, when they take off a lot of fluid I feel awful afterward. So you’ll tell them to go easier next time?

speaker: CONSULT
text: Exactly. We’ll recommend smaller volume removal at your next dialysis session to help keep your blood pressure from dropping so much and reduce your symptoms.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your repeat blood cultures drawn here have shown no growth so far, which is a good sign that the infection is under control. You’ve remained afebrile, your blood pressure is at your baseline, and you’re walking around without dizziness.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That’s good to hear. When do you think I can go home?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Given your stable blood pressure, controlled heart rate, improving potassium, and negative follow-up blood cultures, we’re planning to discharge you later today with home health services. You’ll continue to receive IV vancomycin at dialysis, and we’ll send prescriptions for your HIV medications, dialysis-related meds, and the new diltiazem.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I just moved here and don’t really have doctors yet. How will I get follow-up for my HIV and kidneys?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’re arranging follow-up for you. You’ll need to see a new primary care doctor and an HIV specialist within the next week, and also follow up with your renal doctor. We’ll give you phone numbers to call to schedule those appointments, and we’re also giving you refills for your HIV medications, valacyclovir, dialysis-related meds like cinacalcet and sevelamer, and your prophylactic Bactrim.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I haven’t been great about taking my HIV meds lately. I didn’t always have a place to get them. Is that going to hurt me?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Your HIV labs show a low CD4 count and a high viral load, which means your immune system is quite weak right now. That increases your risk of infections like this line infection. It’s very important to restart and stay on your HIV medications consistently. We’re concerned about your prognosis if the virus stays uncontrolled, so we’re emphasizing close follow-up with an HIV specialist.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I understand. I’ll try to keep those appointments and take the meds like you say.

speaker: NURSE
text: I’m going over your discharge instructions. You’re going home with visiting nurse services. You’ll keep your regular dialysis schedule, and they’ll give you vancomycin through your line at dialysis for the next 11 days. Take diltiazem four times a day for your heart rate, and continue your HIV meds, valacyclovir, sevelamer, cinacalcet, aspirin, Bactrim on Monday-Wednesday-Friday, docusate, and folic acid as prescribed. Call your doctors or come back if you get fever, chills, worsening dizziness, chest pain, or trouble breathing.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Thank you for explaining everything. I’ll make sure to talk to my dialysis doctors about my low blood pressure too.
